metadata.case_name: Rajes Kanta Roy v. Santi Debi

facts.text: Ramani Kanta Roy possessed considerable properties and had three sons: Rajes Kanta Roy, Rabindra Kanta Roy, and Ramendra Kanta Roy.
Rabindra died childless in 1938 leaving widow Santi Debi.
In 1934, Ramani created endowment for family deity appointing three sons as shebaits.
In 1941, Santi Debi sued for declaration as shebait in place of husband; suit terminated in compromise recognizing her right.
In 1944, Ramani and sons Rajes and Ramendra sued Santi Debi declaring 1941 compromise null and void, inter alia on ground marriage within prohibited degrees.
On July 26, 1945, Ramani executed registered trust deed over entire properties appointing Rajes as sole trustee.
Ramani died after execution of trust deed; exact date not on record.

Suit compromised on December 3, 1946; Santi Debi gave up rights under 1941 decree, agreed to monthly allowance of Rs. 475 for life from November 1946, payable by execution on default of four months; properties (Bharatkhali in Rangpur) charged for payment; option for receiver.
Monthly allowance paid up to end of February 1948; default thereafter.
Santi Debi filed execution application on July 8, 1949 for arrears March 1948 to July 1949 (Rs. 8,075) against Rajes and Ramendra by attachment/sale of premises No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road.
Rajes filed objection under s.47 CPC; Ramendra did not object.
Subordinate Judge, Alipore, Original Order No. 100 of 1950 (decree July 18, 1950) overruled objections.
Calcutta High Court dismissed appeal by judgment/decree March 10, 1952.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether under the compromise decree, personal remedy available only after exhausting remedy against charged properties (Bharatkhali property).
Whether Rajes' interest in properties under trust deed, particularly premises No. 44/2 Lansdowne Road, is contingent and not attachable.
Whether there is an executable decree (minor objection).

petitioner_arguments.text: Under compromise decree, charge created over properties; personal remedy only after exhausting charge; decree-holder relinquished rights in other properties.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Construction of compromise decree cls. c, d, e; Bombay High Court cases

petitioner_arguments.text: Under trust deed, Rajes has no attachable interest; only trustee interest or contingent interest after debts discharged and settlor's death.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Cl.12 trust deed; Pestonjee Bhicajee v. P.H. Anderson; ss.19,21 TPA; ss.119,120 ISA; Bernard v. Mountague

petitioner_arguments.text: No formal executable decree; no direction to pay Rs.475 monthly.

respondent_arguments.text: Compromise decree provides unqualified personal remedy under cl.c; cls.d,e give liberty/option for charge/receiver, not obligatory first resort.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Construction of cls. c,d,e of compromise

respondent_arguments.text: Rajes' interest under trust vested, not contingent; entire income applied for benefit after limited payments; devolves on heirs.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: ss.19,119 TPA/ISA; Ranganatha Mudaliar v. A. Mohana Krishna Mudaliar

court_reasoning.text: Overruled minor objection: Formal order incorporates solenama as decree per Bengal practice; executable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No indication point raised below; not defeating execution.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.c gives unqualified personal remedy; cls.d,e optional; no obligation to exhaust charge first; cl.j does not alter.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Intention clear from wording; personal remedy available simultaneously.

court_reasoning.text: Rajes' interest in Lots I-IV vested: Postponed enjoyment for debt discharge, but income (limited + surplus for debts) for benefit; devolves on heirs; no uncertainty in debt discharge contemplated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bias towards vested unless contrary clear; scheme earmarks lots proportionally.

court_reasoning.text: Premises 44/2 Lansdowne Road: Vested interest restricted in enjoyment (residence right till alternative house provided); not contingent; trust ends on debts/settlor death.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Subjection to cl.12c affects absolute devolution post-trust, not vesting.

holdings.text: Personal remedy under compromise decree available without exhausting charge.
Rajes' interest under trust deed vested and attachable, including in premises 44/2 Lansdowne Road.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pestonjee Bhicajee v. P. H. Anderson
Ranganatha Mudaliar v. A. Mohana Krishna Mudaliar
precedents_cited.relevance: Interest vested despite payment of debts clause.
Payment of debts as condition precedent to vesting in some cases.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, overruled objections under s.47 CPC, upheld executing court's order allowing attachment and sale of premises No. 44/2 Lansdowne Road for arrears of maintenance allowance; no opinion on undis-charged debts or unprovided accommodation.
outcome.relief_granted: Execution proceeds against Rajes' interest in the property.

key_quotes.text: It is quite clear that cl. c gives her an unqualified right to obtain payment of the monthly allowance from the plaintiffs. Clauses d and e give her a liberty or option to pursue the remedies specified therein.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Construction allowing personal remedy without exhausting charge.

key_quotes.text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that in so far as the interest of Rajes is concerned in lots I to IV under the trust deed, it is vested and not contingent.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on nature of interest being attachable.
